Is this thing on? Very excited to launch the Facebook page for my official Senate office today. Here, my staff and I will post updates of what’s happening in the office, on the floor, and around Ohio, with a few photos of Franklin here and there as well. Like us, and make sure to tell your friends to like us too! -SB

Americans are working too hard for too little. It’s time we restore the value of work in this country.  I’ll be speaking about my plan to make work pay again at 10:30am today in Columbus. We’ll have it right here on Facebook Live - tune in. -SB
Making hard work pay off.

I had a great morning in Columbus discussing my new plan to restore the value of work. Afterwards, I got to catch up with a few of the folks whose letters and  stories inspired these policies.    As I said this morning – the value of work is not about the color of your skin. It’s not a blue-collar issue or a white-collar issue. It’s not liberal or conservative. When we talk about work, we talk to everyone.   I’m glad to have the conversation. -SB
Touched by this random act of kindness in Port Clinton. Looking forward to watching these students pay it forward.

Our Columbus office recently welcomed transgender rights activist Melissa McLaren and her twins – her daughter, who’s transgender, and her son. Her daughter spoke about how lucky she is to have a supportive family that allows her to be herself, which she knows not every transgender child has. She said there’s nothing more important to her than making sure our transgender community receives equal, fair treatment.   We must continue to fight for Title IX and the protections that children like Melissa’s deserve. Schools must be places where all children feel safe and welcome to learn.

Ohioans have called my office terrified of losing their healthcare because of the House plan. We cannot allow Washington politicians who get taxpayer-funded health insurance to rip coverage away from Ohioans who are battling cancer, getting regular checkups for the first time, or finally getting treatment to beat their opioid addiction. This plan will raise prices for Ohioans – particularly older Ohioans – and kick people off of the coverage they have today. It will threaten jobs across our state by cutting funding for local hospitals that employ hundreds of thousands of Ohioans. This plan does nothing to lower healthcare costs for Ohioans, but hands a huge tax break to drug companies and insurance executives who jack up their prices. -SB

Today, I was proud to write a letter with Senator Rob Portman​ that urged action against the anti-Semitic threats we’ve seen across the country. I was even prouder that it was signed by all 100 members of the U.S. Senate.   As we wrote in the letter, these cowardly acts aim to create an atmosphere of fear and disrupt the important programs and services offered by Jewish Community Centers to everyone in the communities they serve. We are concerned that the number of incidents is accelerating, and failure to address and deter these threats will place innocent people at risk and threaten the financial viability of JCCs, many of which are institutions in their communities.  Read the full letter here:  https://www.brown.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/brown-portman-join-full-senate-in-letter-to-trump-administration-urging-action-against-anti-semitic-threats  -SB

WATCH: On the floor tonight, Sherrod read letters from Ohioans who are terrified of losing their healthcare.   As one woman from Beachwood wrote: "Please consider the people who will be affected the most."
This display of discrimination and intimidation is reprehensible and has no place in Ohio. Each of us has a responsibility to stand against hate and injustice wherever we see it.

On International Women’s Day, we celebrate the women in Ohio and across our nation who have shaped the course of our history, and worked to make our country better – but we must not rest until every woman around the globe has the opportunity to harness her power and her abilities to reach her potential.

Proud to work with U.S. Senator Susan Collins, Senator Bill Nelson, and Senator Shelley Moore Capito on our new legislation to protect Medicare patients from high medical costs after time spent under “observation status.”   Seniors should be able to focus on their recovery instead of billing technicalities and sky high medical bills. Our legislation offers a simple fix, and it's the least we can do to protect our seniors from outrageous medical costs that they have no control over. -SB

Today, Senator Rob Portman and I are honored to invite Ohio’s students to apply for nominations from our Senate offices to U.S. Military Service Academies.   Ohio’s students have the integrity, courage, and knowledge needed to enroll in our nation’s prestigious military academies. These institutions develop the next generation of leaders who will serve our country as military officers and national leaders.   For more information on the application process and to sign up for an Academy Seminar, please visit: https://www.brown.senate.gov/services/students/academy-nominations  -SB

You may have heard me speak about my days at Johnny Appleseed Junior High School in Mansfield, Ohio. Today happens to be National Johnny Appleseed Day.   Our school’s namesake was known for his generosity of spirit, as he traveled the country and planted apple seeds that would one day bear fruit for all to enjoy. His last known tree still stands in Ashland County, a reminder to take care of the earth and to take care of others – and to eat your apples. -SB

As an Eagle Scout myself, I was honored yesterday to speak at the Greater Cleveland Council’s Annual Eagle Scout Recognition Ceremony.   My parents were very different people – he a doctor, she a teacher; he a conservative, she a liberal; he a Republican, she a Democrat; he a Northerner, she a Southerner – but they instilled in my brothers and me the perseverance and the commitment to community that we all need to become Eagle Scouts.   They taught us to live by the call in the oath to “help other people at all times.”   The values we cherish as Eagle Scouts aren’t about what you look like or what zip codes your parents live in. We can recognize the qualities of an Eagle Scout – leadership, service, perseverance – in people throughout our lives. -SB

Today's report from the Congressional Budget Office affirms the fears I’ve heard from Ohioans that this plan will kick millions off their insurance and drive up costs for others, especially older Americans. More than 200,000 Ohioans have received treatment for opioid addiction through the Affordable Care Act and we can’t leave them, working Ohioans, and people with disabilities with nowhere to turn. It’s shameful Washington politicians who get taxpayer-funded healthcare are continuing to force this bill on the American people even after learning it will take away coverage from 14 million Americans by next year. -SB

I was honored to have Rita Lewis of West Chester, Ohio, join me a few weeks back at my speech about restoring the value of work.   I met with Rita last year when she was in Washington to testify in front of the Senate Finance Committee in honor of her late husband, Butch. Butch worked as a trucker for 40 years with the promise that the pension he earned would be there to care for his family after he retired. In fact, he led the Southwest Retirees Pension Committee’s fight against cuts to their earned benefits. He passed away on New Year’s Eve due to a stroke, which doctors have attributed, at least in part, to the stress he faced over the proposed pension cuts. When Rita and I met, her widow benefits had already been cut and she faced an additional 40 percent reduction because of the proposed cuts put forth by Central State.   This is disgraceful. If a pension fund is in bad shape, it’s our job to fix it – not to break our promises to Ohioans who have worked their whole lives to earn that pension. I believed that three years ago when I voted against the law that allowed these proposed cuts, and I believe it now.   Butch once said the cuts being forced on retirees amount to a war against the middle class and the American Dream - and he’s right. Ohio’s retired workers have earned their pensions and retirement savings over a lifetime of hard work – whether it’s behind a desk, on the factory floor, down in coalmines or behind the wheel.   My new plan includes ideas on how we can make it possible for more workers to save for retirement. As I said in Columbus, part of the bargain we have in this country is that if you work hard your whole life, you ought to be able to spend your later years with your grandkids – not trying to make ends meet.   After the speech, Rita gave me this framed picture of her and Butch, as well as the picture of her and I when we first met in Washington. I’m keeping it in my office as a reminder of what we’re fighting for. -SB   #MakeWorkPayMonday

The Federal Government may have opened late today, but Ohio farmers weren’t going to let a little snow slow us down. Great to speak at the Ohio Farm Bureau Federation breakfast this morning. Look forward to working with you to make sure Ohio priorities are represented in the next Farm Bill.

The next US Trade Representative must be committed to putting American workers and manufacturers first, and aggressively cracking down on China’s trade violations. Watch Sherrod press Robert Lighthizer on just how he’d overhaul our failed trade policies.

Thanks to Dr. Steve Allen of Columbus’ Nationwide Children's Hospital for sharing this story.   The facts here are simple: the House’s healthcare plan puts the Medicaid coverage of 30 million children at risk – affecting the 1.2 million children insured by Medicaid in Ohio. This is unacceptable.   As Dr. Allen writes: “If we care about children in our city, in our state and in our country, we must care about what happens to Medicaid.”
The Ukrainian community in Ohio and around the world knows firsthand the dangers of unchecked Russian aggression – which is why we must strengthen our current sanctions against Russia.
We keep America safe by aggressively going after terrorism, not by shutting our doors to doctors, students and families who are fleeing the same terrorists we are fighting against. -SB
Excited about our new bill supporting American manufacturers and good-paying American jobs, and proud to work with Senator Rob Portman on what's right for Ohio.

Last month, I spoke on the Senate floor about the harmful algae blooms that left 500,000 Ohioans without safe drinking water for 3 days in 2014, and the need to further protect our Great Lakes.   This morning, we learned that President Trump’s budget blueprint eliminates the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative entirely. This move will cost Ohio jobs and jeopardize public health by putting the well-being of Lake Erie at risk. As a kid, I remember seeing how polluted Lake Erie was, and we can’t put an end to our cleanup efforts when we’ve made such progress. My colleagues in the Ohio delegation and I will not stand for a budget that zeroes out this critical program. -SB

This week, my office received these petitions of thousands upon thousands of Ohioans against Gorsuch’s nomination.   As I’ve said before, Judge Gorsuch has ruled that corporations are people and given them more rights than everyday Ohioans. We need Supreme Court justices who will defend the rights of working families over Wall Street and corporate special interests — and Judge Gorsuch’s record doesn’t pass that test. -SB

Great to meet with Secretary of Defense James Mattis last week and discuss the pressing need to address sexual assault and harassment in the military, as well as our defense necessities in Ohio - particularly upgrading our C-130H planes at Youngstown Air Reserve Station and Mansfield Lahm Air National Guard Base. We were honored to extend an invitation for him to visit Wright-Patterson Air Force Base and the Air National Guard 178th Wing in Springfield.
CLEVELAND: it's not too late to sign up for tomorrow's workshop about growing your own small business as a new American. Proud to cosponsor with Senator Rob Portman. RSVP at ow.ly/KDeF309RHuW.

On this #MakeWorkPayMonday, hear directly from one Ohio small business owner who wrote to me about what he’s doing to make hard work pay off for his employees. Steven Hill, a pizza shop owner in Columbus, wrote to me about raising the minimum wage. Not only that, he told me that businesses shouldn’t be able to reward investors until they pay their workers above what would qualify them for government assistance.  He was absolutely right. If his small business can pay his workers a living wage in Ohio, why should major corporations get away with relying on taxpayers to pick up the tab for their workers? I was so moved by Steven’s letter that I invited him to be my guest at President Trump’s Joint Address to Congress in Washington last month, where we were able to talk more about his ideas.  Read more about my plan to restore the value of work in America here: https://www.brown.senate.gov/all-pressworking-too-hard-for-too-little  -SB

The Evangelical Lutheran Church in America wrote a letter to Congressional leaders, expressing their concerns about the drastic cuts to Medicaid under the new House plan.  Rev. Elizabeth Eaton writes, “As Christians, we join with many in other religions in announcing that God calls all people and governments to do justice and to give priority to the needs of the most vulnerable people—the aging, the young, the sick and those with disabilities. Therefore, we are committed to working as a church with other individuals, organizations, and the government to ensure the continuation of Medicaid as a guaranteed benefit.”  Proud to fight alongside the ELCA to protect Medicaid and the coverage it offers to millions of Ohioans.

Happy National Ag Day! Grateful for the farmers across the country who keep our families fed.   On this particular Ag Day, I want to share a story about the generosity of Ohio’s agricultural community. After watching devastating wildfires blaze through several states, farm families from across our state banded together to build up a caravan of trucks carrying hay and feed to farmers in need.   As one of the caravan’s organizers said, “Agriculture is a really cool industry to be a part of because people take care of each other.”   -SB

If you serve our country, you’re entitled to the education benefits you’ve earned. It should be simple as that – but it’s not. Too often, our troops and veterans are bogged by student loan debt, or are missing the crucial support they need to transition to their campus.   Yesterday, I introduced a new bill called the Education Development for Troops and Veterans Act, to support our men and women in uniform by helping more servicemembers earn and use their education benefits and protecting those who volunteer to serve from getting hit with student loan bills before going on deployment. Our country’s servicemembers deserve our full gratitude and protection, and I’ll always support them.   -SB

To judge is to be faced with choices.  When Judge Gorsuch has been faced with choices in his career, he’s always favored the powerful few over everyday Americans. He’s chosen corporations over workers, Wall Street over working families, and special interest money over grassroots activists.
WATCH: Sherrod pressed Jay Clayton this morning on how he’d handle matters affecting Trump Administration officials and conflicts of interest as SEC Chair.

Sherrod is using every opportunity he has to fight the opioid epidemic. We know this problem has hit rural communities particularly hard. So today Sherrod held Agriculture nominee Sonny Perdue’s feet to the fire about how he will use his role at USDA to help.

Fentanyl has taken far too many lives across Ohio, and this is one concrete step we can take right now to help stop it from entering our communities and destroying any more Ohio families. It’s not enough to treat overdoses as they happen – we must do more to stem the tide of deadly synthetic opioids flooding the country. We know hi-tech screening works and we need to give CBP agents the tools they need to keep fentanyl from entering the U.S. Proud to work with Senator Edward J. Markey, Senator Marco Rubio, and Senator Shelley Moore Capito on this important issue. -SB

It’s no secret why this bill didn’t have the votes to pass the House today – it’s a bad deal for the people we serve. Blocking this plan is a victory for the mother who wrote me about the services her son gets for autism, the people I’ve met who are treating their opioid addictions, the seniors who rely on Medicaid to stay in their nursing homes, and thousands more Ohioans who depend on coverage through the Affordable Care Act. Instead of wasting any more time threatening to take health insurance away from working families, Congress needs to move on and work together to lower costs and improve healthcare for everyone. -SB

One of this week’s highlights: getting a visit from Dave and Norm of United Mine Workers of America. Proud to stand with them in the fight to get the healthcare and pensions that they’ve earned over a lifetime of backbreaking work.

Our hearts are broken for the families of the victims and the entire Cincinnati community. Connie and I are grateful to the police and first responders who responded to the scene and the medical personnel caring for the injured. We ask everyone to join us in praying for their recovery. My office will offer any assistance we can as law enforcement continue to investigate. -SB

Mr. Boehm lived a life of service. He served our nation in World War II and served our community by bringing together young people from all walks of life through his Singing Angels chorus. Mr. Boehm’s work emphasized the diversity and the capacity of the northeast Ohio community, and the Singing Angels continue to honor that legacy today.  Connie and I extend our deepest sympathies to Mr. Boehm’s family and friends. -SB

On this #MakeWorkPayMonday, I want to share just one reason why it’s so important that we restore the value of the work in this country.   Richard from Mentor, Ohio summed it up well in a letter to me last year:   “It seems companies want to put more and more on workers’ backs but let them share less and less in the profits. Because of that, I’m very worried about my son’s and my grandson’s futures.”   Richard reminds us that the value of work isn’t just about the number that appears on a paycheck. When we talk about the value of work, we’re talking about families - because if work isn’t valued, Americans can’t earn their way to a better life for their children.   That’s what this four-part plan is all about – it’s for Richard and for every parent and grandparent that wants to make sure their kids can do better than they did. Read more here: https://www.brown.senate.gov/all-pressworking-too-hard-for-too-little  -SB

Military readiness begins with individual readiness, which in turn depends on family readiness. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) deserves our strong and continued support – and attacking the funding, structure, or independence of the CFPB only makes its work on behalf of our troops harder.   Proud to support their important work with my colleague Senator Jack Reed, the ranking member of the Senate Committee on Armed Services.

One third of bank tellers working for banks are on government assistance - and the CEOs of the top 5 banks make 470 times the annual salary of the median front-line bank worker.   When we talk about economic growth, we need to talk about policies that help everyday Americans.

A happy coincidence today: a great meeting about criminal justice reform with Anquan Boldin, Donte Stallworth and Johnson Bademosi turned into a chance for the NFL players to take questions from northeast Ohio students in town on a tour of our nation’s HBCUs.
WATCH: Sherrod speaks out against Congress’ vote to get rid of online privacy protections.

Glad to see the US Women’s National Hockey Team will finally receive equitable compensation and resources in comparison to their male colleagues.  When women are paid unfairly in the workplace – whether that’s a bank, a factory floor, or an ice rink - it means less money to save for retirement, put gas in the car, or pay down student loans. It’s bad for our economy, and it’s just plain wrong.

The cost of prescription drugs in this country is skyrocketing – and we cannot ask Ohioans to choose between paying for medicine and putting gas in the tank or food on the table.   President Trump said he wanted to lower drug costs, and our new legislation offers concrete proposals to make that happen. Proud to introduce the Improving Access to Affordable Prescription Drugs Act, and thanks to U.S. Senator Al Franken for his leadership on this important issue. Learn more here: https://www.brown.senate.gov/newsroom/press/release/brown-introduces-prop
Joined 45 senators yesterday to send a simple message to President Trump: Don’t sell Americans’ personal information to the highest bidder. Veto this bill.
There's no day like Opening Day. Ready for a great season with the Cleveland Indians – if they ever need a sore-armed left handed relief pitcher, they know who to call. #RallyTogether  -SB

On this #MakeWorkPayMonday, let’s talk about overtime.    When you work extra hours, you should make extra money. Period.   Kevin wrote me last year from Warren, Ohio, and told me about the challenges he faces as an overextended salaried employee, working 55 to 65 hours a week with no possibility of overtime:   “I am forced between a decision of accepting a salary based job that will require me to lose a heavy portion of my quality of life, or taking an hourly position and not making enough to make ends meet. I work enough hours that a second job is impossible, yet as taxes and inflation rise, and the economy worsens, it is expected for the labor laws to not apply to me because I make just enough to survive.”   This is unacceptable. My new plan stipulates that overtime pay be extended to executive, administrative, and professional workers making less than $47,476.  Folks working long hours should reap the benefits, regardless of whether they earn an hourly wage or a salary.    -SB

Tonight, the Senate passed legislation that will clear the way for the Delta Queen, a U.S. National Historic Landmark, to once again carry passengers on overnight trips on the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers.   The Delta Queen is not just a treasured Cincinnati landmark – it is an opportunity to create jobs and boost tourism revenue. Senator Rob Portman and I will keep working on this effort until Ohio passengers and visitors to our state can embark on this historic ship from our Queen City. -SB

On Equal Pay Day, I reintroduced legislation that would put an end to pay discrimination based on gender. The Paycheck Fairness Act would close loopholes that allow women to continue to be paid less than men.  We cannot allow Ohio women to be cheated out of wages they’ve earned. It hurts working families and our economy when women earn less than men for the same job. -SB

Today, we remember Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the 49th anniversary of his assassination.  As we honor Dr. King’s legacy, we remember what he taught us about the arc of our moral universe – it bends toward justice. But we can’t forget what else he said about that arc – it’s long. So we must never be discouraged and instead recommit ourselves to fighting for justice each and every day.

“I was very familiar with Gorsuch’s record when he was announced. Trump had made clear that he was only going to nominate somebody who wanted to overturn Roe v. Wade. Second, there’s enough in Judge Gorsuch’s record that he believes that corporations are people and that fundamentally gives corporations more rights than individual citizens.”   Read Sherrod’s full interview with Cleveland Magazine: https://clevelandmagazine.com/in-the-cle/politics/articles/sherrod-brown

WATCH LIVE: Sherrod speaks out against Judge Gorsuch and his troubling record of ruling for the powerful few over everyday Americans.

From Sherrod’s eulogy, delivered at John Glenn’s Celebration of Life on December 17th, 2016:  “By any measure – accomplishment, service, courage – John Glenn was a great man.  But when I think of John Glenn, I think of a good man.  My first taste of John Glenn, the good man, was on March 4, 1968, at the Madison Theater in Mansfield, Ohio.   More than fifty teenage boys had gathered for our Eagle Scout Dinner.  Colonel Glenn was the speaker.    John Glenn, national hero, met each of us.  John Glenn, perhaps the most famous man of his generation, took a picture with us – one at a time.  He always took time for you, no matter your station in life.   And that lesson has stuck with me.    Almost 39 years later, former Senator John Glenn walked me down the center aisle of the United States Senate to be sworn in.  And of course – like the Eagle Scouts of four decades earlier – all the new senators wanted to meet their American hero.  He was kind to them too....  .....A former Glenn staffer told me that, “John Glenn took joy in helping others and was so proud of his staff.  Even when you left, you were still family.”  John had a way of making everyone around him feel important – from the teenage Eagle Scouts to the farmer in the field. He lived his life by Matthew 25: Jesus admonished his followers, "Whenever you did it for any of my people, no matter how unimportant they seemed, you did it for me."  That was John Glenn. The great American hero, was a good man.”

It was an honor to lead a Congressional Delegation with Senator Rob Portman to Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, Ohio last month. The work done at Wright-Patt is critical to our national security, and it’s important that members of Congress and other decision-makers in Washington understand that. Thanks to Senator Mazie K. Hirono, Senator Jack Reed, and Senator John Boozman for joining us.   Check out photos of our visit here: https://www.brown.senate.gov/newsroom/gallery/photos/codel-

Last night’s missile strike appears to be a proportional response for Assad’s brutal killing of innocent civilians, but there are still unanswered questions, including how the strike will impact American forces on the ground fighting ISIS and what this means for long-term military engagement in Syria. President Trump needs to come up with a strategy to resolve the Syrian conflict, share his plans with the American people and win their support before taking further action.   Secretary Tillerson is scheduled to travel to Moscow next week, and he and President Trump need to use this Administration’s close ties with Russia to pressure President Putin to step up and curtail further indiscriminate killing of Syrian civilians. -SB

You may have heard me talk about how much I love my Jeep Cherokee: it’s built with American steel by union workers in Toledo, and nothing will keep you safer. A bittersweet day at Fiat Chrysler Automobiles’ Toledo Assembly Complex as they move toward their next assignment – but glad to see the 700 new jobs that will come to Northwest Ohio as a result. -SB
13 years ago I married the love of my life. Happy anniversary, Connie. -SB  Photo credit: NASA HQ.

The GI bill’s education benefits are critical to our returning servicemembers, veterans, and their families. It’s our duty to ensure that when the men and women who sacrifice for our nation return home, they and their families have the education and the training they’ve earned. Proud to work on this effort with Senator Thom Tillis. -SB
WATCH: Sherrod's message from Progressive Field before the Cleveland Indians home opener this afternoon - hear why he's wearing a Dayton Dragons hat today.

Great to meet with northwest Ohio workers at UAW Local 14 in Toledo this morning, and hear about their priorities as the Administration moves to renegotiate NAFTA.  Donald Trump made a lot of big promises during his campaign, including to overhaul our trade policy and renegotiate NAFTA within his first 100 days in office. I’ve always stood up to Presidents of both parties to fight for better trade deals for Ohio. And I’m going to hold NAFTA renegotiation to the same standard I’ve always used for every trade deal, no matter who was in the White House: does it put Ohio workers first? I’m ready to work with President Trump to deliver on his promises, or to hold him accountable if he doesn’t. -SB

Joined with 20 Senators yesterday to demand answers from United Airlines.   As we wrote in our letter to the corporation’s CEO, “Consumer trust and confidence are critical to ensure this industry continues to thrive, and we hope United Airlines will work diligently to immediately address this incident and make necessary improvements to ensure it does not occur again.”

Last night, PBS shared the story of the great Ohioan Eddie Rickenbacker – America’s most successful fighter ace in World War I and a Medal of Honor recipient.  Proud to honor his legacy with the Rickenbacker Air National Guard Base in Columbus.

Two great roundtable discussions about infrastructure in Akron and Canton today.   Our parents and grandparents left us with infrastructure that was the envy of the world, but too many of our roads, bridges, and railways have fallen into disrepair. We have a chance to put Ohioans to work across our state. We can create jobs repaving and repairing our streets, rebuilding bridges, eliminating lead from older homes, upgrading our water and public transit systems, and building broadband networks across the state. -SB

After years of backbreaking and dangerous work, Ohio miners are now faced with the fear of losing the benefits they earned. They were promised retirement security and health benefits – security they sacrificed pay raises and their own health for. They descended into our nation’s mines every day to hold up their end of that bargain – now we’ve got to hold up ours. We made a promise to these workers, and I will fight like hell to make sure Congress keeps it.  As part of upholding that promise, I recently reintroduced the Black Lung Benefits Act. Too many miners who risked their lives in our nation’s mines now suffer from Black Lung disease due to their work underground. They shouldn’t have to navigate a difficult claims process dominated by red tape. -SB
Great to see LeBron James continuing to give back to northeast Ohio. Excited to watch the I Promise School blossom in Akron.

Connie and I join Ohioans in praying for the full recovery of everyone injured in last night's shooting. Like many today, we will hug our family a little tighter after this devastating news and hope the families of the victims will be able to do the same very soon.   We are grateful to the medical professionals caring for the injured as well as the the police and first responders at the scene. News of gun violence in our communities is always heartbreaking - especially on a weekend meant for celebrating with family, and so soon after last month's nightclub shooting in Cincinnati. As always, my office will offer any assistance we can as law enforcement investigate. -SB

Connie and I are grateful to the police for their ongoing work to keep our community safe and bring the shooter to justice. We encourage anyone with information to please come forward. My office will provide any assistance we can as law enforcement investigate.   We join our fellow Clevelanders in feeling shock and sadness that something like this could happen in our city. Too many acts of violence have shaken Ohio communities recently, and our thoughts remain with the families of Mr. Godwin and other victims and the law enforcement officers working to protect us all. -SB

On this #MakeWorkPayMonday, let’s talk about paid family leave.   Jenny wrote to me from Delaware, Ohio about her concerns as a 27-year old woman who’s planning on getting pregnant in the next few years:  “I have been with my place of employment for 4 years and if I want to have a child, I would need to not use any sick or vacation time for the next 2 years to ensure that I get a few weeks with my newborn.   We are, of course, under FMLA allowed up to 12 weeks unpaid leave but I do not know any of my coworkers….who can afford to do this. Frankly, I don't know any person in any profession that can afford to do this. I know of many other women across multiple fields facing this same dilemma. I know women who worked past their due date to save up this vacation and sick time.”  Our current labor laws put women - and men - in a place they shouldn’t be in when deciding to have a child: no prospective parent should have to worry about how having a baby will affect their next paycheck.  That’s why I introduced the FAMILY Act, which creates an insurance plan that provides workers up to 12 weeks of paid family or medical leave. With this benefit, we give workers more power over their own lives and futures.   -SB

President Trump promised Ohioans his Administration would put American workers and American products first, and today’s action is one step toward looking for improvements to Buy America. But reviewing Buy America alone won’t put construction workers back on the job, and until we apply Buy America to all our infrastructure and public works projects, we will allow this business to go to foreign countries at the expense of Ohio taxpayers.  It’s simple: American tax dollars should go toward American-made steel that supports American jobs. That’s why I’ve asked President Trump to work with me on my legislation to use American steel and iron and American labor to build all taxpayer-funded infrastructure projects. I hope President Trump will follow his review of Buy America policies with firm action that puts our workers on the job rebuilding our infrastructure using products made here in the U.S.  -SB

Honored to receive the Jane Daroff Lifetime Achievement Award from PFLAG Cleveland yesterday. A great celebration of the organization's work for Ohio's LGBTQ community - and learning how to use a selfie stick was just an added bonus.

On this #MakeWorkPayMonday, let’s talk about subcontracting – and how it can hurt workers.   The truck driving sector has been just one example of an industry where employers have shifted their workers from full-time to independent contractors as a way to reduce workforce costs. Misclassifying workers as independent contractors just to boost corporate profits is wrong.   When workers are misclassified as independent contractors, they miss out on wages and benefits and job security that full-time employees receive. They’re also on the hook for more payroll taxes, and left vulnerable without important federal labor protections. A survey of port truck drivers found that independent contractor drivers earn 18% less than direct employee drivers – and 82% of these drivers were independently contracted.   My plan to restore the value of work prevents large employers from using the independent contractor classification to get around labor laws and boost profits by taking advantage of workers.  No worker should be cheated so their employer can make an extra buck. -SB

Equifax's data breach put the spotlight on forced arbitration - which bars consumers from going to court in the event that they're cheated.  Forced arbitration clauses live in the fine print. When you sign certain contracts, you may be signing away your rights.  After the fake account scandal, Wells Fargo's arbitration clauses continue to prevent customers from seeking justice. Luckily, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB)’s rule will stop banks and payday lenders from using arbitration to limit your rights – but that rule is under attack in Congress.  Congress must support the CFPB rule and stand with you, not Wall Street. Take advantage of the CFPB's resources before you sign financial contracts: https://www.consumerfinance.gov/arbitration-rule/  But banks and payday lenders aren't the only abusers of forced arbitration - it exists in footnotes and fine print of all kinds of contracts. The nursing home industry is one repeat offender - many contracts force residents to give up their rights. Certain employers even include forced arbitration clauses in their contracts. Some for-profit colleges include forced arbitration clauses in their enrollment contracts for new students.   Before you ever click "I agree" or sign a dotted line - always read the fine print.
